qas.question: How many previously-separate phyla did the 2007 study reclassify?
What did the 2007 study decide was the parent group for annelids?
What offshoots of polychaetes are unsegmented?
What offshoots of polychaetes are only segmented in the rear?
What nervous system structure is less univeral among annelids than was thought before 2007?
How many previously-separate phyla did the 1837 study reclassify?
What did the 2007 study decide was the slave group for annelids?
What offshoots of polychaetes are immortal?
What offshoots of polychaetes are only segmented in the head?
What nervous system structure is less universal among annelids than was thought before 1907?

context: In addition to re-writing the classification of annelids and <a0_0><b5_0>3<b5_0/><a0_0/> previously independent phyla, the molecular phylogenetics analyses undermine the emphasis that decades of previous writings placed on the importance of segmentation in the classification of invertebrates. <a1_0><b6_0>Polychaetes<b6_0/><a1_0/>, which these analyses found to be the parent group, have completely segmented bodies, while polychaetes' <a2_0><b7_0>echiurans and sipunculan<b7_0/><a2_0/> offshoots are not segmented and <a3_0><b8_0>pogonophores<b8_0/><a3_0/> are segmented only in the rear parts of their bodies. It now seems that segmentation can appear and disappear much more easily in the course of evolution than was previously thought. The 2007 study also noted that the <a4_0><b9_0>ladder-like<b9_0/><a4_0/> nervous system, which is associated with segmentation, is less universal previously thought in both annelids and arthropods.[n 2]
